properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass will remain over the Maritimes through Wednesday. Maximum daytime temperatures near 30 degrees will persist over much of New Brunswick today and Wednesday, with overnight lows near 19 C providing little relief. Humidex values of 37 to 39 will also persist. Maximum temperatures along the Bay of Fundy, will be somewhat cooler. However, areas slightly inland are still likely to reach heat warning criteria over the next two days. Temperatures across northwestern portions of the province will cool somewhat on Wednesday as a trough of low pressure begins to move across the region. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T22:48:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T06:49:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3082277592.2019

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This afternoon and this evening, conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts to 40 knots, frequent lightning and poor visibilities due to thunderstorms at times heavy. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This afternoon and this evening, conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Boaters may be surprised by strong gusts over water bodies. ### Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T20:44:36-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times tonight into Tuesday. Rain will continue through Tuesday before tapering off to scattered showers Tuesday evening. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are expected. This rainfall is associated with a low pressure system moving slowly northward over James Bay. Should this system intensify more than expected, a rainfall warning may be required. Environment Canada's rainfall warning criteria is 50 mm in 24 hours or less. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T11:30:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T03:31:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2925221130.2019
Area: Fort Albany

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The heat will persist until this evening; the combination of temperatures and humidity will give humidex values of 35 to 38. Limit physical activity. Drink lots of water, even before feeling thirsty, and keep cool. Check up on elderly family members, friends and neighbours. Make sure that they are staying cool and drinking water. Look for cool places, such as shade from trees, a swimming pool, a shower or bath, and an air conditioned location like a public building. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T16:42:49-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The warm and humid air mass will persist until this evening, the combined values of temperature and humidity will produce a humidex factor of 37 to 40. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. Rain will continue tonight and Tuesday before tapering off to scattered showers Tuesday evening. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 75 mm are expected. There is a chance that the total rainfall may reach 100 mm by Tuesday evening. This rainfall is associated with a low pressure system moving slowly northward over James Bay. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds gusting to 90 km/h are forecast to develop early this morning. Winds will weaken this afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-31T00:24:58-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will remain over the Maritimes over the next few days. Daytime maximum temperatures are expected to reach 30 degrees today and Wednesday. Overnight lows tonight are expected to fall to near 20 degrees providing little relief from the heat. Maximum humidex values of 35 to 38 are expected. Temperatures across the island should cool down somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T22:48:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T06:49:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2674158303.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and humid airmass continues to push into the Maritimes and will persist through Wednesday. Daytime highs over inland areas of Nova Scotia are forecast to be near 30 degrees today and Wednesday with overnight lows near 19 degrees providing little relief. Humidex values are expected to reach 36 to 39 today and Wednesday. Temperatures across the province should cool down somewhat on Thursday as a trough of low pressure moves in from the northwest. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-07-30T22:48:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-07-30T06:49:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4192564813.2019
